awd_titl_txt: Scholarships to Enhance Excellence in the Chemical and Biological Research Based Workforce (STEER)
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at California State University at Fullerton (CSUF) is providing scholarships and support services to academically-talented students majoring in biology, chemistry, and biochemistry who demonstrate financial need. Abundant jobs are available for biology, chemistry, and biochemistry graduates in the bioscience industry, but a gap exists between the available, qualified talent and the burgeoning need for such personnel. CSUF's Scholarships To Enhance Excellence in the Chemical and Biological Research-Based Workforce (STEER) project is addressing this critical shortage by supplying highly-qualified graduates who are capable of functioning in the multidisciplinary, team-based environment that characterizes industry. In addition, a link to CSUF's NSF Noyce Teaching as a Primary Profession in Biology and Biochemistry project invites STEM teachers in preparation to STEER activities, which impacts the bioscience career awareness of future high school teachers and their students.

STEER's overarching goal is to enhance the quantity and quality of CSUF STEM undergraduates who will join the biological and chemical research-based industry workforce. In addition to providing scholarships for at least 80 students, it is integrating new and existing campus activities for students in the targeted majors who wish to enter the biosciences workforce. STEER provides scholarships, support services, and opportunities to ensure students academic and personal support, as well as enrichment activities that enable them to learn, study, socialize, and work together from their scientific perspectives, improving retention, graduation rates, and job prospects. The project is adapting the curriculum to enable students to acquire knowledge, skills, and habits that are specifically tailored to industry careers and needs. Thus, it is establishing programs that will contribute to the knowledge base about ways to effectively educate a robust STEM industry workforce and about the educational practices and experiences that foster retention in STEM majors, completion of degrees, preparation for the workplace environment, and the habits of mind that lead to success in the industry workforce, particularly among underrepresented minorities.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the Scholarships to Enhance Excellence in the Chemical and Biological Research Based Workforce (STEER) provided scholarships to California State University, Fullerton students with majors in the college of Natural Sciences and Mathematics.  The goals are the program were: 

1. Enhance the academic preparation of CSUF undergraduates who will join the biological and chemical research-based workforce.

2. Enhance the preparation of CSUF undergraduates who will join the biological and chemical research-based workforce through early exposure to workforce environments. 

3. Enhance the retention and degree completion of STEM majors of CSUF undergraduates who will join the biological and chemical research-based workforce.  

Goals 1 & 2: We developed a structured pro-seminar where students had the opportunity to develop practical and academic skills (e.g., resume writing, personal statements) as well as develop peer and near-peer connections. The students described peer-networks or mentorship as a necessary resource to be prepared for a job. This was also facilitated by brining faculty, alumni, and guest speakers from industry to speak to the scholars. In addition, we developed a strong collaboration with the CSUF career center which has benefited the STEER scholars and other students in the College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics. The assessments of critical thinking, oral and written communication skills of the scholars have shown gains for students who have participated for more than one semester in the STEER program. 

Goal 3: The STEER program provided support for 49 students from fall of 2014 to spring 2022. These include 31 women, 20 underrepresented students, 34 Pell eligible students, and 10 whose parents did not attend college. 41 (10 after leaving the STEER program) of these students have graduated including 26 women, 18 underrepresented students, 29 Pell eligible students, and seven whose parents did not attend college. The other eight students are on track to graduate. Many of our students have moved on to other programs. One joined the NIH funded Maximizing Access to Research Careers and nine have joined the Bridges to STEM Cell Research program at CSUF.  The STEM Cell Research program provides a pathway to a paid internship and advanced training in STEM cell biology.

The STEER scholars graduated more quickly than students in the College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics that did not have scholarship and programmatic support and also had higher grade point averages. In addition the graduation rates of first generation college students, underrepresented students, and female students were all higher than NSM students who did not receive support. 

The program created provided financial and academic support for CSUF students, helping them move on to positions in the STEM workforce and graduate or professional school. 

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2023
Modified by: Sean E Walker
